Comments_List: I went into this course knowing absolutely no Turkish and came out knowing some basic Turkish.
I developed how to read, write, and speak Turkish.
I developed a basic understanding of how the Turkish language works and also learned a bit about Turkish culture.

A strength of this class is that it was flexible and very engaging. We would sometimes have class in other places on campus which is really fun or if there was something related to Turkish politics, Islam, etc. we wanted to talk about, Selim was happy to discuss it with us. This was nice because I learned a lot about culture outside of just the Turkish language. This course could be improved by making the quizzes less hard. They were quite difficult at times because they used a lot of words that we had not learned before which made it difficult to apply the grammatical structures we were being tested on.
I loved the cultural events and interactions we had in this class. Also, because of the small size of the class, we had a great amount of individual attention.

The textbook was not great and the class could have been structured in a way to make learning easier. Turkish is a challenging language so even for basic concepts a lot of outside the classroom studying needs to be done . The cultural immersion through projects inside the class and outside the class events were the best part of the course.
I would recommend this class to someone interested in Turkish, linguistics, the Middle East, or history. It is a very interesting (albeit hard to learn) language and Selim is great.
Yes, it is a great course to learn Turkish.
I would recommend this class for another student, however, this student would have to be really invested and interested in learning the Turkish language.
